docs.title: Advanced Layer Renamer
docs.text: Professional QGIS plugin for batch renaming map layers with advanced features

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Advanced Layer Renamer is a powerful QGIS plugin that allows you to rename multiple map layers at once using a variety of transformation options. Whether you need to add prefixes, apply numbering, clean up names, or use complex regex patterns, this plugin has you covered.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Smart Numbering

    Add sequential numbers with customizable leading zeros (01, 001, 0001, etc.)

  • Find & Replace

    Simple text replacement or powerful regex pattern matching

  • Case Conversion

    UPPERCASE, lowercase, Title Case, or Capitalized

  • Date Stamping

    Automatically add dates in multiple formats (YYYYMMDD, YYYY-MM-DD, DD-MM-YYYY)

  • Templates

    Save and reuse your favorite naming configurations

  • Validation

    Check for naming issues before applying changes

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
Transform your layer names in seconds:

Before After my layer (copy) 01_Project_my_layer data_2023_final 02_Project_data_2023_final untitled layer 03_Project_untitled_layer

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Common questions and answers about the Advanced Layer Renamer plugin.

docs.title: What QGIS versions are supported?
docs.text: The plugin requires QGIS 3.0 or higher. It has been tested on QGIS 3.0 through 3.34.

docs.title: Does this rename the actual data files?
docs.text:
No. This plugin only renames the layers within your QGIS project. The underlying data files (shapefiles, GeoPackages, etc.) are not affected.

To rename actual files, you would need to:

  1. Export the layer with a new name
  2. Use your operating system's file manager

docs.title: Can I undo a rename?
docs.text:
Currently, there is no built-in undo feature. However:

  • QGIS has a general undo function (++ctrl+z++) that may work in some cases
  • You can close the project without saving to revert changes
  • Consider saving your project before bulk renames

Best Practice

Always save a backup of your project before performing large batch renames.

docs.title: Will this work with layers in groups?
docs.text: Yes! The plugin lists all layers regardless of their group structure. Layer groups themselves are not renamed, only the individual layers within them.

docs.title: How do I add numbers at the end instead of the beginning?
docs.text:
Currently, numbering is added as a prefix. As a workaround:

  1. Leave numbering off
  2. Add your number pattern as a suffix
  3. Use a template for consistency

Feature request: Numbering position is on our roadmap.

docs.title: Can I start numbering from a specific number?
docs.text:
Not yet. Numbering always starts from 1. This is a planned feature for a future release.

Workaround: Add a calculated offset using find/replace with regex after the initial numbering.

docs.title: What regex flavor is used?
docs.text:
The plugin uses Python's re module, which implements Perl-compatible regular expressions.

Common patterns:

Pattern Matches \d Any digit \w Word character (letter, digit, underscore) \s Whitespace . Any character * Zero or more + One or more ? Zero or one ^ Start of string $ End of string

docs.title: Why isn't my regex working?
docs.text:
Common issues:

  1. Escaping: Special characters need backslashes (\. for a literal dot)
  2. Case sensitivity: Patterns are case-sensitive by default
  3. Greedy matching: .* matches as much as possible

Use the Test Regex Pattern button to debug your patterns.

docs.title: Can I use regex in the prefix/suffix fields?
docs.text: No. The prefix and suffix fields only accept literal text. Use the Find/Replace fields for regex operations.

docs.title: Where are templates stored?
docs.text:
Templates are stored in presets.json in the plugin directory:

WindowsmacOSLinux 
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\QGIS\QGIS3\profiles\default\python\plugins\batch_layer_renamer\presets.json

~/Library/Application Support/QGIS/QGIS3/profiles/default/python/plugins/batch_layer_renamer/presets.json

~/.local/share/QGIS/QGIS3/profiles/default/python/plugins/batch_layer_renamer/presets.json

docs.title: Can I share templates with colleagues?
docs.text: Yes! Simply copy the presets.json file and share it. Recipients should place it in their plugin directory.

docs.title: My templates disappeared after updating. Why?
docs.text: Plugin updates may sometimes reset the presets file. Always back up your presets.json before updating.

docs.title: The plugin doesn't show any layers
docs.text:
Possible causes:

  1. No layers are loaded in the project
  2. Plugin opened before layers were added

Solution: Click the Refresh button to reload the layer list.

docs.title: The rename button doesn't do anything
docs.text:
Check:

  1. Are any layers selected?
  2. Does the preview show "Will Change" for any layers?
  3. Are there any error messages?

If all names show "No Change," your settings aren't modifying the names.

docs.title: I get an error about invalid regex
docs.text:
Your regular expression pattern has a syntax error. Common mistakes:

  • Unmatched parentheses: (text should be (text)
  • Unescaped special chars: file.txt should be file\.txt
  • Invalid quantifiers: *+ is invalid

Use the Test Regex Pattern button to validate your pattern.

docs.title: The plugin is slow with many layers
docs.text:
The real-time preview updates with every change, which can be slow with hundreds of layers.

Tips:

  • Select only the layers you need to rename
  • Configure all settings, then click Preview Changes
  • Disable real-time preview by making changes quickly

docs.title: Special characters aren't being removed
docs.text:
Ensure Remove special characters is checked in Advanced Options.

Note: This option keeps letters, numbers, spaces, underscores, dashes, and dots. Only other special characters are removed.

docs.title: How many layers can I rename at once?
docs.text:
There's no hard limit, but performance may degrade with very large numbers:

Layers Performance 1-100 Instant 100-500 Fast 500-1000 May take a few seconds 1000+ Consider batching

docs.title: Why is the preview slow?
docs.text:
The preview regenerates for all selected layers whenever settings change. With many layers, this can take time.

Optimization tips:

  • Select fewer layers at once
  • Make multiple quick changes rather than pausing between each

docs.title: Features
docs.text: A comprehensive guide to all the renaming features available in Advanced Layer Renamer.

docs.title: Numbering Options
docs.text: Add sequential numbers to your layer names.

docs.title: No Numbering
docs.text: The default option. Layer names are transformed without adding numbers.

docs.title: Sequential (1, 2, 3...)
docs.text:
Adds simple sequential numbers as prefixes.

Original Result Layer A 1_Layer A Layer B 2_Layer B Layer C 3_Layer C

docs.title: Leading Zeros
docs.text:
Adds numbers with leading zeros for consistent sorting. Choose the number of zeros:

Setting Example Output 1 (01, 02...) 01, 02, 03... 99 2 (001, 002...) 001, 002, 003... 999 3 (0001, 0002...) 0001, 0002... 9999 4 (00001, 00002...) 00001, 00002... 99999 5 (000001, 000002...) 000001, 000002... 999999

Why use leading zeros?

Leading zeros ensure layers sort correctly in alphabetical order:

  • Without: 1, 10, 11, 2, 3...
  • With: 01, 02, 03... 10, 11...

docs.title: Prefix
docs.text:
Add text to the beginning of layer names.

Prefix Original Result 2024_ Layer 2024_Layer Project_ Data Project_Data

docs.title: Suffix
docs.text:
Add text to the end of layer names.

Suffix Original Result _final Layer Layer_final _v2 Data Data_v2

docs.title: Find & Replace
docs.text:
Replace specific text within layer names.

Simple Text Replacement:

Find Replace Original Result old new old_layer new_layer _ - my_layer my-layer copy `` layer (copy) layer ()

docs.title: Regular Expressions
docs.text:
Enable Use Regular Expressions for powerful pattern matching.

What are Regular Expressions?

Regular expressions (regex) are patterns used to match character combinations in strings.

Common Regex Examples:

Pattern Description Example \d+ Match numbers layer123 → layer (if replaced with empty) \s+ Match whitespace my layer → my_layer (if replaced with _) ^old_ Match "old_" at start old_layer → new_layer _v\d$ Match version suffix layer_v1 → layer \(.*\) Match parentheses content layer (copy) → layer

Test Your Regex:

Click the Test Regex Pattern button to test your pattern against a sample string before applying.

docs.title: Case Conversion
docs.text:
Convert the case of layer names. Only one option can be selected at a time.

Option Original Result UPPERCASE My Layer MY LAYER lowercase My Layer my layer Title Case my layer name My Layer Name Capitalized my layer name My layer name

Note

Case conversion is applied after all other transformations (prefix, suffix, find/replace, etc.)

docs.title: Date Stamping
docs.text:
Automatically add the current date to layer names.

Available Formats:

Format Example YYYYMMDD 20240115 YYYY-MM-DD 2024-01-15 DD-MM-YYYY 15-01-2024

The date is added as a prefix:

Layer Name  →  20240115_Layer Name

docs.title: Remove Special Characters
docs.text:
Removes all characters except:

  • Letters (a-z, A-Z)
  • Numbers (0-9)
  • Spaces
  • Underscores (_)
  • Dashes (-)
  • Dots (.)

Example:

Original Result Layer <v1> Layer v1 Data: 2024 Data 2024 file/path filepath name@domain namedomain

Characters Removed

The following characters are removed: < > : " / \ | ? * @ # $ % ^ & ( ) + = { } [ ] ; ' , ~

docs.title: Clean Extra Whitespace
docs.text:
Removes leading/trailing spaces and collapses multiple spaces into one.

Original Result Layer Layer My Layer My Layer Data Name Here Data Name Here

docs.title: Transformation Order
docs.text:
When multiple options are enabled, they are applied in this order:

  1. Find/Replace (with or without regex)
  2. Remove Special Characters
  3. Clean Whitespace
  4. Add Numbering (sequential or with zeros)
  5. Add Date Stamp
  6. Add Prefix
  7. Add Suffix
  8. Apply Case Conversion

Example with Multiple Options

Settings:

  • Find: old → Replace: new
  • Prefix: Project_
  • Numbering: Leading zeros (01, 02...)
  • Case: UPPERCASE

Transformation: 

old_layer
↓ Find/Replace
new_layer
↓ Add Numbering
01_new_layer
↓ Add Prefix
Project_01_new_layer
↓ Case Conversion
PROJECT_01_NEW_LAYER

docs.title: Preview Table
docs.text:
The preview table shows the effect of your settings in real-time:

Column Description Original Name Current layer name New Name Result after transformation Status "Will Change" (green) or "No Change" (gray)
  • Green background: Name will be changed
  • Gray background: Name will remain the same

Tip

Columns are resizable - drag the column headers to adjust widths.

docs.text: Action Shortcut Select all layers Click Select All Multi-select ++ctrl++ + Click Range select ++shift++ + Click

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will walk you through your first batch rename operation using the Advanced Layer Renamer plugin.

docs.title: Opening the Plugin
docs.text:
There are two ways to open the plugin:

  1. Menu: Go to Plugins > Advanced Layer Renamer
  2. Toolbar: Click the plugin icon in the toolbar

docs.title: The Interface
docs.text: When you open the plugin, you'll see a dialog with three main tabs:

docs.title: Main Tab
docs.text:
The primary workspace divided into two resizable panels:

Panel Description Left Panel Layer selection with Refresh, Select All, Select None, and Invert buttons Right Panel Renaming options and live preview

docs.title: Templates Tab
docs.text: Save and manage your renaming configurations for reuse.

docs.title: Validation Tab
docs.text: Check layer names for potential issues before renaming.

docs.title: Your First Rename
docs.text: Let's walk through a simple example: adding a prefix to all layers.

docs.title: Step 1: Select Layers
docs.text:
1. Open a QGIS project with some layers
  2. Open the plugin
  3. Your layers will appear in the left panel
  4. Click Select All or manually select the layers you want to rename

Tip

Use ++ctrl++ + click to select multiple individual layers, or ++shift++ + click to select a range.

docs.title: Step 2: Configure Options
docs.text:
1. In the Basic Options section, find the Prefix field
  2. Enter your desired prefix, e.g., Project_

docs.title: Step 3: Preview Changes
docs.text:
The preview table updates automatically as you type! You'll see:

Column Description Original Name The current layer name New Name What the name will become Status "Will Change" (green) or "No Change" (gray)

docs.title: Step 4: Apply Changes
docs.text:
1. Review the preview to make sure everything looks correct
  2. Click Rename Layers
  3. A summary dialog will show how many layers were renamed

Congratulations!

You've completed your first batch rename!

docs.title: Adding Sequential Numbers
docs.text:
1. In Numbering Options, select Leading zeros
  2. Choose the number of digits from the dropdown (e.g., "2" for 001, 002...)
  3. The numbers will be added as prefixes

Example Result: 

Layer A  →  01_Layer A
Layer B  →  02_Layer B
Layer C  →  03_Layer C

docs.title: Find and Replace
docs.text:
1. In Basic Options, enter text in the Find field
  2. Enter replacement text in the Replace field
  3. Check Use Regular Expressions for pattern matching

Example: Replace all underscores with spaces 

Find:    _
Replace: (space)

my_layer_name  →  my layer name

docs.title: Cleaning Up Names
docs.text:
1. In Advanced Options, check Remove special characters
  2. Check Clean extra whitespace

This will:

  • Remove characters like < > : " / \ | ? *
  • Keep letters, numbers, spaces, underscores, dashes, and dots
  • Collapse multiple spaces into single spaces

docs.title: Resizable Panels
docs.text: Drag the divider between the left and right panels to resize them according to your preference.

docs.title: Resizable Columns
docs.text: Drag the column headers in the preview table to adjust column widths.

docs.title: Real-time Preview
docs.text: All options update the preview automatically - no need to click a button!

docs.title: Refresh Layers
docs.text: If you add or remove layers in QGIS while the plugin is open, click Refresh to update the layer list.

docs.text:

  • Validation Tools - Check for naming issues

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide covers how to install the Advanced Layer Renamer plugin in QGIS.

docs.title: Method 1: QGIS Plugin Manager (Recommended)
docs.text: The easiest way to install the plugin is through the QGIS Plugin Manager.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Open QGIS
  2. Go to Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins...
  3. Click on the All tab
  4. Search for Advanced Layer Renamer
  5. Click Install Plugin

Done!

The plugin is now installed and ready to use. You'll find it in the Plugins menu.

docs.title: Method 2: Manual Installation
docs.text: If the plugin is not available in the repository or you want to install a development version:

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Download the plugin ZIP file from the GitHub releases page

  2. Open QGIS and go to Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins...

  3. Click on Install from ZIP

  4. Browse to the downloaded ZIP file and click Install Plugin

Alternative: Direct Folder Installation

You can also extract the ZIP file directly to your QGIS plugins folder:

WindowsmacOSLinux 
C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Roaming\QGIS\QGIS3\profiles\default\python\plugins\

~/Library/Application Support/QGIS/QGIS3/profiles/default/python/plugins/

~/.local/share/QGIS/QGIS3/profiles/default/python/plugins/

docs.title: Method 3: From Source (Development)
docs.text: For developers who want to contribute or modify the plugin:

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Git installed on your system
  • QGIS 3.0 or higher

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository: 

    git clone https://github.com/raymukesh/advanced_layer_renamer.git

  2. Create a symbolic link or copy the folder to your QGIS plugins directory

  3. Restart QGIS

  4. Enable the plugin in Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins...

docs.title: Enabling the Plugin
docs.text:
After installation, make sure the plugin is enabled:

  1. Go to Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins...
  2. Click on the Installed tab
  3. Find Advanced Layer Renamer in the list
  4. Check the box next to it to enable

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
To verify the plugin is installed correctly:

  1. Look for Advanced Layer Renamer in the Plugins menu
  2. You should also see a new icon in the toolbar

Toolbar Icon

If you don't see the toolbar icon, right-click on the toolbar area and ensure Plugins Toolbar is checked.

docs.title: Via Plugin Manager
docs.text:
1. Go to Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins...
  2. Click on the Upgradeable tab
  3. If an update is available, select the plugin and click Upgrade Plugin

docs.title: Manual Update
docs.text:
1. Download the latest version
  2. Uninstall the current version (optional but recommended)
  3. Install the new version using any of the methods above

docs.title: Uninstalling
docs.text:
To remove the plugin:

  1. Go to Plugins > Manage and Install Plugins...
  2. Click on the Installed tab
  3. Select Advanced Layer Renamer
  4. Click Uninstall Plugin

docs.title: Plugin not appearing after installation
docs.text:
• Restart QGIS
  • Check if the plugin is enabled in the Plugin Manager
  • Verify the plugin folder is in the correct location

docs.title: Error messages on startup
docs.text:
• Check the QGIS Python console for error details
  • Ensure you have QGIS 3.0 or higher
  • Try reinstalling the plugin

docs.title: Templates
docs.text: Templates allow you to save and reuse your renaming configurations. This is especially useful for maintaining consistent naming conventions across projects.

docs.title: Understanding Templates
docs.text:
A template saves all your current settings, including:

  • Prefix and suffix
  • Find/replace patterns
  • Regex option
  • Numbering style and leading zeros count
  • Case conversion option
  • Date stamping settings
  • Special character and whitespace options

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Configure all your desired renaming options in the Main tab
  2. Switch to the Templates tab
  3. Click Save Current Settings
  4. Enter a descriptive name for your template
  5. Click OK

Naming Tips

Use descriptive names that indicate the purpose:

  • Project_Standard_Numbering
  • Clean_Import_Layers
  • Archive_With_Date

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Go to the Templates tab
  2. Select a template from the Saved Templates list
  3. Click Load Selected Template
  4. Switch back to the Main tab to see the applied settings

Note

Loading a template replaces all current settings with the saved configuration.

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Go to the Templates tab
  2. Select the template you want to remove
  3. Click Delete Template
  4. Confirm the deletion

Warning

Deleted templates cannot be recovered.

docs.title: Quick Templates
docs.text: The plugin includes three pre-configured quick templates for common use cases:

docs.title: Date Prefix
docs.text:
Adds the current date as a prefix to layer names.

Settings Applied:

  • Date stamp: Enabled
  • Date format: YYYYMMDD

Example Result: 

Layer_Name  →  20240115_Layer_Name

docs.title: Clean Names
docs.text:
Cleans up messy layer names by removing special characters and extra whitespace.

Settings Applied:

  • Remove special characters: Enabled
  • Clean extra whitespace: Enabled
  • Numbering: None

Example Result: 

My   Layer <copy>  →  My Layer copy

docs.title: Project Standard
docs.text:
Applies a professional numbering scheme with clean whitespace.

Settings Applied:

  • Numbering: Leading zeros (01, 02...)
  • Clean extra whitespace: Enabled

Example Result: 

Layer A  →  01_Layer A
Layer B  →  02_Layer B

docs.title: Template Storage
docs.text:
Templates are stored in a JSON file located in the plugin directory:

presets.json

docs.title: Template File Format
docs.text:
{
  "My Template": {
    "prefix": "Project_",
    "suffix": "",
    "find_pattern": "",
    "replace_pattern": "",
    "use_regex": false,
    "numbering_style": "leading_zero",
    "leading_zeros_count": 0,
    "uppercase": false,
    "lowercase": false,
    "title_case": false,
    "capitalized": false,
    "date_stamp": false,
    "date_format": "YYYYMMDD",
    "remove_special_chars": true,
    "clean_whitespace": true
  }
}

docs.title: Workflow 1: Standardizing Imported Data
docs.text:
Scenario: You frequently import data with inconsistent naming.

  1. Create a template with:
    • Remove special characters: Enabled
    • Clean whitespace: Enabled
    • Case: Title Case
  2. Save as Clean_Imports
  3. Use whenever importing new data

docs.title: Workflow 2: Project Archiving
docs.text:
Scenario: You need to archive project layers with dates.

  1. Create a template with:
    • Date stamp: Enabled (YYYY-MM-DD format)
    • Prefix: Archive_
    • Leading zeros numbering
  2. Save as Archive_Project
  3. Use when archiving completed projects

docs.title: Workflow 3: Team Standards
docs.text:
Scenario: Your team has specific naming conventions.

  1. Create templates matching your team's standards
  2. Share the presets.json file with team members
  3. Everyone uses the same naming conventions

Sharing Templates

Copy the presets.json file from your plugin directory and share it with colleagues. They can place it in their plugin directory to use the same templates.

docs.title: Do
docs.text:
• Use descriptive template names
  • Create templates for recurring tasks
  • Test templates on a few layers before bulk application
  • Back up your presets.json file

docs.title: Don't
docs.text:
• Create too many similar templates
  • Use generic names like "Template 1"
  • Forget to update templates when conventions change

docs.title: Template not saving
docs.text:
• Check if you have write permissions to the plugin directory
  • Try running QGIS as administrator (Windows)

docs.title: Template not loading correctly
docs.text:
• The template file may be corrupted
  • Delete the problematic template and recreate it

docs.title: Templates missing after update
docs.text:
• Plugin updates may reset the presets file
  • Always back up your presets.json before updating

docs.title: Validation
docs.text: The Validation tab helps you identify potential naming issues before they cause problems in your workflow.

docs.title: Why Validate?
docs.text:
Layer names with certain characteristics can cause issues:

  • File export failures - Invalid characters prevent saving
  • Database errors - Special characters may conflict with SQL
  • Cross-platform issues - Some characters aren't allowed on all operating systems
  • Sorting problems - Names may not sort as expected
  • Display issues - Very long names get truncated

docs.title: Steps
docs.text:
1. Go to the Validation tab
  2. Select layers to validate (or use Select All in the Main tab)
  3. Click Validate Selected Layers
  4. Review the results

docs.title: Understanding Results
docs.text:
Results are displayed with status indicators:

Icon Meaning Valid - No issues found Warning - Potential issues detected

docs.title: Invalid Characters
docs.text:
The following characters are flagged as potentially problematic:

Character Name Why It's Problematic < Less than Not allowed in Windows filenames > Greater than Not allowed in Windows filenames : Colon Not allowed in Windows filenames " Double quote Not allowed in Windows filenames / Forward slash Path separator in Unix/Mac \ Backslash Path separator in Windows \| Pipe Not allowed in Windows filenames ? Question mark Not allowed in Windows filenames * Asterisk Wildcard character

Fix with Remove Special Characters

Enable Remove special characters in the Advanced Options to automatically remove these characters.

docs.title: Name Length
docs.text:
Names longer than 255 characters are flagged.

Why it matters:

  • Most file systems limit filenames to 255 characters
  • Long names may be truncated when exporting
  • Some databases have field length limits

docs.title: Empty or Whitespace Names
docs.text:
Names that are empty or contain only whitespace are flagged.

Examples of problematic names:

  • `` (empty)
  • (only spaces)
  • \t (only tabs)

docs.title: Leading/Trailing Spaces
docs.text:
Names with spaces at the beginning or end are flagged.

Original Issue Layer Leading space Layer Trailing space Layer Both

Why it matters:

  • Can cause duplicate name issues
  • May not display correctly
  • Can cause matching/search problems

Fix with Clean Whitespace

Enable Clean extra whitespace in the Advanced Options to remove leading/trailing spaces.

docs.title: Common Issues Reference
docs.text:
The Validation tab includes a quick reference panel listing common naming issues:

Common Naming Issues to Check:
• Invalid characters: < > : " / \ | ? *
• Names starting/ending with spaces
• Very long names (>255 characters)
• Duplicate names
• Empty names
• Names with only numbers
• Special characters in file paths

docs.title: Before Renaming
docs.text:
1. Open the plugin
  2. Go to the Validation tab
  3. Click Validate Selected Layers
  4. Review any warnings
  5. Go to Main tab and configure options to fix issues
  6. Preview changes
  7. Validate again if needed
  8. Apply the rename

docs.title: After Importing Data
docs.text:
1. Import your data layers
  2. Open the plugin
  3. Validate all layers
  4. Apply the Clean Names quick template if issues are found
  5. Rename to fix issues

docs.title: Example 1: File Export Preparation
docs.text:
Scenario: Preparing layers for export to Shapefile

Validation finds: 

⚠️ Layer<2024>: Invalid character '<', Invalid character '>'
⚠️ Data/Points: Invalid character '/'
✅ Clean_Layer: Valid

Solution:

  1. Enable Remove special characters
  2. Preview changes
  3. Apply rename
  4. Export files successfully

docs.title: Example 2: Database Import
docs.text:
Scenario: Preparing layers for PostGIS import

Validation finds: 

⚠️ My Layer Name: Contains spaces (may need quoting in SQL)
⚠️ layer-with-dashes: Dashes may cause issues
✅ layer_underscore: Valid

Solution:

  1. Use Find/Replace: Find (space), Replace _
  2. Use Find/Replace: Find -, Replace _
  3. Apply changes

docs.title: Example 3: Cleaning Imported Data
docs.text:
Scenario: Data imported with messy names

Validation finds: 

⚠️  Layer Name : Leading/trailing spaces
⚠️ Layer  Name: Multiple consecutive spaces
⚠️ Layer (copy) (1): May indicate duplicate
✅ Clean_Layer: Valid

Solution:

  1. Enable Clean extra whitespace
  2. Use Find/Replace to remove "(copy)" text
  3. Apply changes

docs.title: Regular Validation
docs.text:
• Validate before major exports
  • Validate after importing external data
  • Validate before database uploads

docs.title: Fixing Issues
docs.text:
• Use Remove special characters for invalid chars
  • Use Clean whitespace for spacing issues
  • Use Find/Replace for specific patterns

docs.title: Prevention
docs.text:
• Establish naming conventions for your team
  • Create templates that enforce clean names
  • Validate early and often

docs.title: Validation vs. Preview
docs.text:
Feature Purpose Validation Checks current names for issues Preview Shows what names will become after transformation

Use both together:

  1. Validate to identify current issues
  2. Configure options to fix issues
  3. Preview to verify the fixes
  4. Apply the rename
